channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Former Military Chief Refuses to Testify in Bosnia Genocide Trial
item.description: The presence in the same courtroom of Radovan Karadzic, the former political leader, and Ratko Mladic was the first joint public appearance appearance since the end of hostilites.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Mass Slaughter of Vulnerable Shark Species in China, Wildlife Group Says
item.description: A wildlife group says businesses in China are slaughtering and processing hundreds of sharks yearly, including members of the whale, basking and great white species, in contravention of international wildlife trade laws.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A worker amid shark parts at the factory in Puqi, in Zhejiang Province.

item.title: Ukrainian Premier Offers to Resign
item.description: Prime Minister Mykola Azarov made the offer only hours before he appeared likely to be stripped of his powers in a vote of no confidence in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Baaouarta Journal: Lebanese Cringe as a Breakdown in Government Wafts Uphill
item.description: Since the government resigned 10 months ago, Parliament has scarcely convened, no major laws have been passed and trash overflows in Beirut — forcing residents to live with the stench.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fayyad Ayyash overlooking the landfill that has been a source of governmental and sensory anguish for residents of Baaouarta, a hilltop village in Lebanon.

item.title: Ukrainian Premier Submits Resignation
item.description: Mykola Azarov’s resignation on Tuesday comes as Ukraine has been gripped by protests for two months.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Ink: How Rahul Gandhi Did in His First TV Interview
item.description: Political analysts weighed in on the Congress Party vice president’s handling of pointed questions by Arnab Goswami of Times Now.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi, vice president of Congress party, addressing party supporters in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, on Nov. 7, 2013.

item.title: China Appears Set to Force Times Reporter to Leave
item.description: Austin Ramzy would be the second Times correspondent obliged to leave mainland China in 13 months because of an unprocessed visa application.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Crackdowns on Live Poultry Sales Mar Holiday Season
item.description: Hong Kong began culling 20,000 live chickens just days before the Lunar New Year, and several areas of China are banning the trading of the live birds.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Workers disposing of dead chickens at a wholesale market in Hong Kong.

item.title: Publisher of Book Critical of China’s Leader Is Arrested
item.description: Family and friends of Yiu Mantin believe he was singled out for arrest because of his plans to distribute a withering denunciation of President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Irving Milchberg, Who Smuggled Guns Under Nazis’ Noses in Warsaw, Dies at 86
item.description: As a street urchin in Warsaw, Mr. Milchberg managed to escape being sent to concentration camps while he smuggled guns and food to the resistance.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH BERGER
item.media:description: Irving Milchberg, left, in 1944 with a fellow cigarette seller from Warsaw nicknamed Conky.

item.title: Court Grants Peru Ocean Territory Claimed by Chile
item.description: The International Court of Justice settled a six-year maritime dispute, slicing about 8,000 square miles of the Pacific Ocean from Chile’s territory.
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: DealBook: Anxiety Rising Over Relations Between Japan and China
item.description: The ties of the neighbors with a long history of strained interactions were a major topic at the World Economic Forum.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan at the World Economic Forum last Wednesday.

item.title: Holocaust Scholar Returns Top Award to Hungary in Protest
item.description: Randolph L. Braham, a Holocaust survivor and professor, said the government’s effort to whitewash the country’s role in the death of Jews had shocked him.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Gang Leader Is Arrested
item.description: Dionisio Loya Plancarte, who is believed to handle public relations for the Knights Templar, was found hiding in a closet in Michoacán and arrested, Mexican authorities said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: United States to Deliver Helicopters
item.description: Congress has approved the delivery of six Apache attack helicopters to the Iraqi military, Pentagon and congressional officials said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Broadcast Chief Apologizes for Comment on ‘Comfort Women’
item.description: The chairman of Japan’s public broadcaster apologized Monday after drawing criticism for saying that his nation should not be singled out for forcing women into sexual servitude during World War II.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Second Cargo of Chemical Agents Leaves Syria as Pace Is Criticized
item.description: The concern is that the schedule of deadlines to destroy the weapons stockpile is falling dangerously behind.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Naval forces on a ship in the Mediterranean wait to take chemical agents from Syria.

item.title: At Neutral Site, Syrians Feel Free to Confront the Other Side
item.description: Frank, even tense, encounters in Geneva have in some ways been the most significant action at peace talks that have been more about optics than results.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Bouthaina Shaaban, center, a Syrian presidential adviser, was confronted at breakfast by an opposition activist.

item.title: A Discredited Supreme Court Ruling That Still, Technically, Stands
item.description: Korematsu v. United States, the 1944 decision endorsing the mass detention of Japanese-Americans during World War II, has long been thoroughly discredited — but the court has not yet repudiated it.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM LIPTAK
item.media:description: People of Japanese descent awaited transport to an internment camp in 1942, with U.S. troops at right.

item.title: Syria Talks Fail to Yield Pact to Lift Aid Blockade
item.description: Little progress was seen in the third day of talks on authorizing an international convoy to enter blockaded areas in the city of Homs.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Muscular West Coast Worker Is on Way to Build New Tappan Zee
item.description: The Left Coast Lifter, a floating crane that can hoist 1,900 tons at a time, passed through the Panama Canal this month. Its use will save time and money in replacing the Tappan Zee Bridge.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH BERGER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Valenzuela for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Magnifico!” one man shouted as the crane passed through the Pedro Miguel Locks. “Its size — I’ve never seen anything like that.”

item.title: Egypt’s Ruler Eyes Riskier Role: The Presidency
item.description: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, who ousted Egypt’s first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi, said he was yielding to the will of the people in taking the first formal step to run for the office himself.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi may run to become Egypt’s president.

item.title: Ukraine’s Leader to Revoke Curbs on Dissent, but Opposition Remains Wary
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovych agreed to revoke new laws restricting political dissent, but two opposition leaders rebuffed his offer to be named prime minister and vice prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A demonstrator took a rest from the protests on Monday in Kiev, Ukraine. Protesters withdrew from the Justice Ministry building they had seized on Sunday.

item.title: Former Exit Port for a Wave of Cubans Hopes to Attract Global Shipping
item.description: The Mariel port, where desperate refugees once crammed onto boats to flee the country, has been upgraded at a cost of about $900 million and holds the government’s hopes of connecting Cuba and the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: Scissors were kept at the ready for a ribbon-cutting ceremony on Monday at the renovated port of Mariel, on the northwestern coast of Cuba.

item.title: U.S. Market Slump Easing; Europe and Asia Still Sliding
item.description: Stocks continued to fall in Europe and in emerging Asia-Pacific markets as slowing growth in China and the prospect of less stimulus in the United States raised the specter of capital flight.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY and BETTINA WASSENER
